data.text: Bike Touring and Coffee Making on the Go

Hi All, any advice for coffee making on the go, avoiding instant coffee? While camping or just out for a ride? For example any recommendations for small cafetiere or filter systems you can use with a gas stove
Mokka pot, most essential thing to take
data.author: Laurence Reeves
Laurence Reeves

data.text: Just buy some empty tea bags and instead of tea put coffee in them.... Works great.
data.author: Rivers Mitchell

data.text: Aeropress the most important thing on my packing list.
data.author: Sarah Greatorex

data.text: Aeropress or Aeropress Go (more compact version).
data.author: Neil Cater

data.text:
https://www.aeropress.co.uk/products/aeropress-go
AeroPress GO
aeropress.co.uk
data.author: Neil Cater

data.text: Mine has been used in work for the past four years each day (there are no other coffee facilities apart from instant), camping trips and holidays, I took a flask of hot water and my Aeropress on an overnight drive through France to the Alps stopping off to make a coffee. It goes everywhere with me. I did have a French press cup/mug but the Aeropress is so much cleaner. I use a metal filter for convenience too.
data.author: Neil Cater

data.text: Love my stainless French press!
data.author: Carolyn Wallace McZazubek

data.text: I prefer instant sleeves, since I'm fine with a rehydrated perfect brew & folded wrapper as discardable stir stick, but I graduated from coffee to tea anyway. I carry a 4oz ISO Butane canister, remote hose fueled burner with folding leg supports, 40 oz can as wind screen, 20 oz can as pot, lighter, tiny pliers as pot holder, light weight mug, & several black tea bags.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: I go cowboy coffee. Water ground coffee on top and boil for 5 mins. Turn off heat. Let sit 1 min. Gently pour slowly into cup. Coffee sinks to bottom of saucepan.
data.author: Simon Cox

data.text: Cowboy coffee and a reusable filter in a pour-over cone (which can be any discarded tin can and a couple sticks, pretty much.)

data.text: Jetboil with the French press kit. Small, boils fast.

data.text: Jetboil heats the water in about 30 seconds and if you use their French press setup, it works wellÔøº. I have the Jetboil Zip.

data.text: Mud coffee, cowboy coffee, whatever you call it. Just needs ground coffee and water. If you can‚Äôt be arsed to heat it, steep it overnight. A bit of a fallacy that you need boiling water. Then dried milk powder. Yummy. üôÇ

data.text: Hands down Aeropress in my book. Used it for a 3 month (motorcycle) tour and my wife and I enjoyed a good cup of hot joe every morning. Easy to use, clean, and maintain.

data.text: AIRSPRESSO https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2447615068867346&id=100008566292760
data.author: Davie Lin

data.text:
Hi Sam I use a thing called Nanopresso from Wacoco, it is the BEST. Makes amazing espresso, no filters or anything needed, beautiful crema , has a cup built in, you just need the Nanopresso, coffee, and hot water. Packs down small, and not too heavy. They have other products too - some pod compatible etc Failing that, and if you can live without a good crema, I used to make a filter out of a cone of fabric and some wire, and just pour your hot water/coffee mix through that. VERY light and takes up no space, but the Nanopresso definitely makes a better coffee https://www.wacaco.com/pages/nanopresso?gclid=Cj0KCQjwuuKXBhCRARIsAC-gM0jNWf0S0b9QRHzInXdgvAONp-vGwa5JPxkCegRbgPnwvo7XzJYfoWoaAq_AEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds
NANOPRESSO
wacaco.com

data.text:
Alot of coffee snobs swear by the aeropress, however I picked up one of these at an REI years back and I love it!! It is so easy to clean (save on water!) It works for a slow infusion cold brew or for pourovers. And I just keep it attached to my thermos, so it takes up very little space https://www.questoutdoors.com/copy-of-gsi-halulite-cup-14-oz.html
GSI HALULITE H2JO!

data.text: Also side note, or fun hack, if you are low on water and typically start your mornings with oatmeal, try making a cup of oatmeal with coffee instead of water. Adds a little more flavor, too!

data.text: I have a small manual grinder and use an Aero-Press. Makes great coffee, easy clean up, light weight, and easy to pack. Life is too short for crappy coffee!

data.text: Robert Timms coffee bags. This is the lightest bring-along that gives best satisfaction for its convenience. Maybe if you can see if this or alternatives are available.

data.text: There's a French press option with certain model jetboil stoves so you can have minimal dishes.
data.author: Ryan Jeambey

data.text: I use a Fire Maple stove (a Jetboil knockoff) that can have a French press option, but I only ever use the stove to boil water, to minimize cleaning. I use a Widesea camping coffee press with it and pre-ground coffee in a bag. I'm a dad on a budget, rather than an Aliexpress shill, but you can get them from there or Amazon at a reasonable price (side note, I wanted other, name brand stuff like a Jetboil, but they just weren't available in South Korea). Some guys go all out and bring beans, a grinder etc, but I just use dark roast pre-ground coffee.
data.author: Mark Thorrowgood

data.text: Stove& Pan to boil water in? I got a paper filter cone support from Ortlieb, & found a reusable filter of cotton fabric.. bought vacuum packed ground coffee in stores...
